Expectation1: Be friendly and polite in daily interactions
Situation1: A noise complaint has circulated on the floor, and a face-to-face meeting in the lobby calls for extra courtesy.
Expectation2: Arrive at the polling station during designated voting hours
Situation2: Late-afternoon errands leave just a couple of hours before the polls close.
Story:
I stepped into the lobby, clutching my grocery bags, just as the elevator doors slid open and Mrs. Kim from 4B waved me over. A few neighbors had gathered, their faces tense. The noise complaint—about loud music late at night—was the talk of the floor, and everyone expected me to join the conversation, to be friendly and polite, maybe even help smooth things over. I could see the hope in their eyes, the silent plea for neighborly support.

But as I glanced at the clock above the mailboxes, my heart thudded. The polling station would close in less than two hours, and I still had to drop off the groceries and pick up my ID. Voting was important to me; I’d promised myself I wouldn’t miss it. Yet here I was, torn between the expectation to be a good neighbor—present, courteous, helpful—and my duty as a voter, to show up before the polls closed. My mind raced, guilt and anxiety tangling together, as I stood rooted in the lobby, feeling the weight of both roles pressing in from either side.
